title: 109_hr2046
content: The Act titled "Servicemembers' Health Insurance Protection Act of 2005" limits premium increases for reinstated health insurance of servicemembers released from active military service. The Servicemembers Civil Relief Act limits premium increases for reinstated health insurance of servicemembers, ensuring that the premium amount does not exceed the original charge before termination. The Servicemembers Civil Relief Act restricts health insurance premium increases for reinstated servicemembers, maintaining the original premium amount. Amendments include technical changes to ensure continuity of coverage. SEC. 3. PRESERVATION OF EMPLOYER-SPONSORED HEALTH PLAN COVERAGE FOR CERTAIN RESERVE-COMPONENT MEMBERS WHO ACQUIRE TRICARE ELIGIBILITY. The amendment allows individuals to continue or reinstate coverage under certain circumstances related to military service or eligibility for medical and dental care under specific sections of title 10. This includes the cancellation of such order, as if the person had become reemployed upon termination of eligibility. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS TO VETERANS BENEFITS IMPROVEMENT ACT OF 2004. Section 2101 of title 38, United States Code is amended by inserting a new subsection (c) with modifications to the text of the previous subsection (c) as in effect before the enactment of the Veterans Benefits Improvement Act of 2004. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall take effect as of December 10, 2004, as if enacted immediately after the enactment of the Veterans Benefits Improvement Act of 2004 on that date. SEC. 5. Notification to member's spouse or next of kin regarding certain elections under Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance Program. Repeal of subsections (f) and (g) of section 1012 of the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act for Defense, Global War on Terror, and Tsunami Relief Act, 2005, and notification requirement for life insurance options under title 38, United States Code. Life insurance options under title 38, United States Code include various elections and applications for insurance coverage, as well as beneficiary designations. The Secretary concerned must notify unmarried members eligible for insurance under this subchapter when they marry. When a member marries under this subchapter, the Secretary must inform the spouse in writing about the member's insurance status. If the member is insured, the notification includes details such as the insurance amount being less than the maximum allowed and any beneficiary designations other than the spouse or child. Notification efforts are made in good faith to reach the spouse or designated person at their last known address. Failure to notify the spouse or designated person in a timely manner about the member's insurance status does not affect the validity of any life insurance option. The House of Representatives passed the bill on May 23, 2005.
